Clean Kangaroo

The goal of this project is to create an app that helps college students in Australia find laundry services near them. The app will allow students to find laundry services nearby and check out their reviews, and prices. If they like what the company has to offer then they can request a service. The laundry service will send a crew to pick up their clothing. Once it's done the clothing will be sent back to them.

We are targeting college students because most of them are lazy and they are not as tidy as they should be. With the stress of exams and working on lots of projects, it's hard to make time for a simple task such as doing their laundry. It would be much easier if they could delegate the task to a credible laundry service. The best way to reach young people is through a web app or a mobile app. The current generation is very tech-savvy so we have to use technology to reach out to them instead of just putting flyers on the college campus.

I used the following color palette to give the app a feeling of tidiness and cleanliness. The blue color can be associated with laundry detergent. Most cleaning chemicals have a blue color. So when the users use the app the blue color will help them associate the app with cleanness. The accent colors are shades of the primary blue color. These colors will help create contrast within the app. Instead of using several different colors, which will confuse the user, it is better to use shades of the same color. That way the app has contrast but also consistency. The white color is essential to creating a feeling of comfort and relaxation. An app always needs plenty of white space so that it feels easy on the eyes. Those are feelings we want to associate with an app that provides a cleaning service.

Because we are dealing with college students we need a font that is cool and hip. I used Rubik and Karla to achieve this. Rubik was used for the headers and Karla was used for the body. The contrast between the two fonts creates a nice visual hierarchy. In any design, you donâ€™t want multiple items competing for attention. Using color and fonts you want to create a noticeable contrast so that users know what is important and what is not.

After figuring out the main details I went ahead and made a couple of detailed sketches to help me think about the actual interface and how all the different components will come together. Understanding the target audience makes it much easier to think of features. During this phase, I try to come up with as many ideas as possible. Over time I will narrow down the details and figure out what will stay and what will go.

Interaction design is a crucial aspect of any application. User flows help me think about the different paths a user can take. I think about potential animations and where they can be placed in the flow. I always make sure to keep things simple and think about the most efficient way of getting users from A - B. After doing user testing some of these planned interactions may change, but that is fine. The design process is iterative, not linear. We wonâ€™t get everything right the first time.

This is the most exciting part of the design process. You get to bring your designs to life. Everything comes together into a beautiful masterpiece. When I put everything together I can see what went well and what could be improved. If something doesnâ€™t feel right I will make a note of it. This is a great time to do testing with users but also with other designers. The quicker we identify problems the sooner we can fix them and improve the overall user experience.

Large-scale projects take a long time to complete. I am currently working on creating the right animations and mico-interactions. Once I am done I will make sure to add it over here.
